articles.title: New Zealand's foreign minister raises concerns about China's live-fire drills during Beijing visit
articles.summary: Winston Peters met with Wang Yi in Beijing to discuss the recent live-fire drills in the Tasman Sea. New Zealand and Australia are concerned about the lack of notice given to them by the Chinese government. Mr Peters believes that Wang Yi took New Zealand's concerns on board.

articles.title: BCWS, Upper Nicola Band plan controlled burns in Quilchena area
articles.author: James Peters
articles.summary: The B.C. Wildfire Service is planning fuel management burns in the Interior. There is a planned 30-hectare burn in conjunction with the Upper Nicola Band next Monday. The project will take place in multiple areas of Quilchena IR #1, about 25 km northeast of Merritt.

articles.title: How does bird flu affect Canada?
articles.summary: Large outbreaks of bird flu are hitting the U.S., driving up poultry prices. CTV's Dylan Dyson reports on how Canada is taking precautions to prevent the same thing happening in their country.    iReport.com: Do you know anything about bird flu in Canada?

articles.title: The two year fight to stop the Redfish Pointe development continues
articles.author: Andrew Shipley
articles.summary: On Saturday Protect Our Wetlands in Cape Coral will protest against the development of Redfish Pointe next to Rotary Park. The developers are trying to get the zone changed for the area to include 800 multi-story residential units, a 300-bed resort hotel and retail and restaurant space. Chris Robben is concerned about the impact of the development on the mangroves protecting south Cape Coral from storm surge. Matt DePaolis is the Environment Policy Director with Sanibel Captiva Conservation Foundation.

articles.title: Living with extreme heat might make you age faster
articles.author: The Verge
articles.summary: Exposure to extreme heat could have a huge impact on climate change.    The Verge has a data-has-syndication-rights for this article.  It's available on The Verge's website and on the website of The Verge’s news partner.

articles.title: Doomsday Clock is closest its ever been to human extinction, but University of Chicago scientists remain optimistic
articles.author: Joe Donlon
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock was moved up to 89 seconds last month. It's the closest the world has ever been to total annihilation. The goal of the clock is to scare people and inspire them to take action. Daniel Holz is optimistic about humanity's future despite the grim message it conveys.

articles.title: Tracking winds and cooler days on the way
articles.author: Melissa Zaremba
articles.summary: Unseasonably warm temperatures will persist into Friday with highs trending 10-15 degrees above normal. A weak, dry disturbance will move into the region on Thursday, bringing breezy to windy conditions and slight cooling. Stronger weather systems are expected to move through the Desert Southwest this weekend and into next week.

articles.title: Reasons Why Regulating CO2 Emissions Needs to be Reconsidered
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: EPA Administrator is considering revoking the 2009 CO2 Endangerment Finding. The science of human-caused climate change is more uncertain that you have been led to believe. Global energy imbalance caused by increasing CO2 emissions is smaller than the accuracy with which we know natural energy flows in the climate system. The IPCC's official reports do not claim that our greenhouse gas emissions have caused changes in severe weather.

articles.title: Matt Cormier: Our Body Temperatures Are Dropping Around the World: Have We All Become Immune System Compromised?
articles.author: Lioness
articles.summary: One-time or recurring donations can be made through Ko-Fi. Matt Cormier's video series is concerning as our body temperatures are collectively dropping around the world, which is an indicator of chronic illness, immune system suppression and metabolic disease.98.6°F (37°C) is considered healthy resting body temperature.

articles.title: Extreme Heat May Cause Older People to Age Faster, New Study Finds
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: A first-of-its-kind analysis found that people living in hotter areas experienced more molecular changes than those in cooler places. The study was published in the journal "Molecular Structure and Structure of Molecules".      .

articles.title: Gulf of America or Gulf of Mexico? How Some Communities Are Responding
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: President Trump's order changing the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America has prompted many communities along the coast to think about the basin in a way they never had before.      .   "Gulf of Mexico" is the name of the Gulf basin.

articles.title: Encroaching desert threatens to swallow trans-Saharan homes and history
articles.author: SAM METZ
articles.summary: As the world's climate gets hotter and drier, sandstorms are depositing inches and feet of dunes onto Chinguetti's streets and in people's homes, submerging some entirely. Tree-planting projects are trying to keep the invading sands at bay, but so far, they haven't eased the deep-rooted worries about the future.

articles.title: How Climate Change Will Affect the Seasons
articles.author: Time Magazine
articles.summary: Last year was the warmest on record and the first time the average global temperature exceeded 1.5°C above the pre-industrial average. Global warming is already being felt around the world, as the Earth sees warmer than average temperatures. The Earth's system is in a precarious balance.

articles.title: Caribbean's '25 by 2025′ extended to 2030 with new ‘resilient, sustainable' goals
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Guyana's President Dr. Irfaan Ali announced the extension of the region's ambitious 25 by 2025 food security initiative to 2030 with additional resilient and sustainable goals. The initiative was developed during the COVID-19 pandemic to cut food imports by 25 per cent by 2025. The 2030 food security agenda will incorporate a tech-driven agricultural sector and includes greater participation from women and young people.

articles.title: Glacial Melting Is Accelerating, Driving Sea Level Rise and Depleting Freshwater: Study
articles.author: Michael Riojas
articles.summary: The world's glaciers have been losing 273 billion tonnes of ice mass annually, causing oceans to rise by nearly a millimeter per year. The second half of the period studied from 2012 to 2023 saw a 36% increase in ice loss compared to the first half. In the lower 48 and western Canada, glaciers have lost 23% of their volume since 2000.

articles.title: Along the Gulf, Residents Wonder: What's in a Name?
articles.author: Rick Rojas
articles.summary: President Trump changed the name of the Gulf of America to 'Gulf of America' in an executive order last month. Many Gulf Coast residents are happy with the name change, but others are not. Some news organizations continue to use the name Gulf of Mexico, while others stick with it.

articles.title: 26th Harbin Ice-Snow World closes
articles.author: 新华网
articles.summary: The 26th Harbin Ice-Snow World in Harbin, northeast China's Heilongjiang Province, officially closed on Wednesday as temperatures rise. An aerial drone photo taken on Feb. 25, 2025 shows tourists visiting the Harbin ice-snow world.

articles.title: Population and climate: looming catastrophe
articles.author: Durdana Najam
articles.summary: Pakistan has a population of 250 million people and an annual growth rate of over 2%. Pakistan is one of the most rapidly expanding populations in the world. The population growth has a negative impact on the environment, climate change, urban planning and economic sustainability. Pakistan's urban expansion is haphazard, driven by real estate interests rather than environmental considerations. There is a need for a national policy that prioritises sustainable urban planning, family planning and environmental conservation.

articles.title: Ontario election day 2025 weather: Wet, snowy conditions expected — but here's when you might catch a dry break to head to the polls
articles.author: Evelyn Harford
articles.summary: Temperatures are expected to cool late Thursday into Friday as another shot of Arctic air comes down over southern and eastern Ontario and cools the air temperature.   .   i   in the late afternoon and early evening Thursday and into Friday.

articles.title: Coast Guard warns public about icy waters as temps warm
articles.author: Coast Guard
articles.summary: The Coast Guard is urging the public to exercise caution around icy waters as temperatures fluctuate across the Great Lakes region. Temperature fluctuations have impacts on the structural integrity of the ice and could pose safety concerns for those planning to recreate on or near ice and cold water.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Linked to Accelerated Aging in Older Adults, Study Finds
articles.author: Mohana Ravindranath
articles.summary: A new study suggests that heat waves and rising temperatures from climate change could be chemically modifying people's DNA and speeding up their biological aging. It is the first population-level analysis to establish a connection between heat exposure and epigenetic aging in humans, building on separate research finding similar changes in fish, mice and guinea pigs.

articles.title: Scientists discover extreme heat can accelerate aging
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: People living in areas with more hot weather days show faster aging at the molecular level than residents of cooler regions, according to a study by the University of Southern California USC Leonard Davis School of Gerontology. It raises new concerns about how climate change and heatwaves could affect long-term health. Older people are particularly vulnerable to the effects of high heat.

articles.title: Scientists discover extreme heat can accelerate aging
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Extreme heat may speed up the aging process in older people, according to a new study. It was originally published on talker.news, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, and is republished here by request of the talker news service.

articles.title: Scientists discover extreme heat can accelerate aging
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Extreme heat may speed up the aging process in older people, according to a new study by Stephen Beech, a scientist at the University of Michigan.      .   "Extreme heat could be dangerous for older people."  "It could be harmful for everyone.

articles.title: Scientists discover extreme heat can accelerate aging
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Extreme heat may speed up the aging process in older people, according to a new study by Stephen Beech, a scientist at the University of Michigan.      .   "Extreme heat could be dangerous for older people."  "It could be harmful for everyone.

articles.title: Coastal Flooding Technical Workshop March 19
articles.author: Juliet Kaszas-Hoch
articles.summary: The coastal flooding technical workshop is being organized by the N.J. Coastal Resilience Collaborative and the Stevens Institute of Technology. It's scheduled for Wednesday, March 19, at the Stevens campus in Hoboken. Speakers include Tom Herrington, Jon Miller, Amanda Archer and Chris Huch from Black & Veatch Corp.

articles.title: Why where you live could ‘speed up the ageing process' – as study warns areas at risk
articles.author: Eliza Loukou
articles.summary: People living in areas with more extreme heat aged faster than those living in cooler areas. The study was conducted by the University of Southern California USC Leonard Davis School of Gerontology. It looked at 3,600 people aged 56 and older across the United States.

articles.title: Why where you live could ‘speed up the ageing process' – as study warns areas at risk
articles.author: Eliza Loukou
articles.summary: People living in Phoenix, Arizona, experienced higher rates of biological ageing than those living in cooler regions. The study was conducted by the University of Southern California USC Leonard Davis School of Gerontology. It found a correlation between more days of extreme heat and greater increases in biological age in older people living in areas with more heat.

articles.title: How Climate Change Will Affect the Seasons
articles.author: Simmone Shah
articles.summary: As Earth continues to warm, summers will get longer and winter months will get shorter. A longer summer can increase wildfire risks in the West, while the Northeast and Midwest are expected to see an increase in winter precipitation. The climate crisis disproportionately impacts the lowest income countries and communities of color.

articles.title: AP experiences rise in temperatures
articles.author: DC Correspondent
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh is experiencing a significant rise in temperatures across most districts. The weather department has issued a five-day forecast warning of continued high temperatures. Nandyal and Kurnool recorded the highest temperatures at 36°C, while several other cities experienced temperatures well above 33°C.

articles.title: Rising disasters in Kasese threaten lives and livelihoods
articles.summary: Rising disasters in Kasese threaten lives and livelihoods. Benjamin Jumbe examines the human toll of these disasters. He explores ongoing interventions aimed at helping communities build resilience.   .   i   in the past decade, the region has experienced a rise in the frequency and intensity of disasters such as flooding, mudslides, and landslides.

articles.title: Tropicana facing financial issues amid citrus industry struggles
articles.author: Spectrum News Staff
articles.summary: Tropicana, one of the largest employers in Manatee County, could be headed for bankruptcy. European private equity firm just gave Tropicana an emergency $30 million loan. The company is also facing supply shortages due to hurricanes Helene and Milton.

articles.title: Aussie hot spots too dangerous to live by 2090, and why Melbourne and Hobart could come up trumps: Climate Council
articles.author: Nathan Mawby
articles.summary: There will be dozens of extreme heat days every year in most parts of northern Australia by 2090. The Northern Territory electorate of Lingiari will have 235 days above 40 degrees each year. The Franklin electorate will average just one day above 35 degrees, and the Flinders electorate will have just 10 days. The number of nights above 25 degrees will shoot from one to 33. The seat of Casey in Melbourne's south east is expected to more than quadruple its number of hot days from three to 14. The Mallee region along the Murray river in the north west of the state will be its hottest electorate with 58 days above 35 Celsius. In South Australia the data shows the seat of Grey will

articles.title: Few relief options for Henderson County farmers — local growers face $135 million loss
articles.author: Jennifer Heaslip
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene devastated Henderson County, North Carolina. The county lost $135-$150 million in crop losses, but only about $38 million of that was due to infrastructure damage. There are four national relief programs available for farmers, but none of them covers direct revenue loss. $31 billion has been approved for agriculture relief nationwide.

articles.title: Pakistan Literature Festival 2025: Experts Discuss Climate Change Impacts
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: The second day of the Pakistan Literature Festival 2025 featured a session titled "Global Temperature Rise: An Impending Disaster" Urdu Point and Pakistan Point News broadcast on 26th February, 2025 on Urdu point and Pakistan point news.

articles.title: What Is The Actual Impact of Climate Change On Humans, If Any?
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: The most immediate impact of climate change is the alteration of weather patterns worldwide. The changes can have cascading effects on local economies, especially those reliant on farming and tourism. Climate change poses a severe threat to global food security, agriculture and water resources. It can also have a psychological and economic impact.

articles.title: Beyond the burn: Harvesting dead wood to reduce wildfires and store carbon
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A century of fire suppression, combined with global warming and drought, has led to increasingly destructive wildfires in the Western United States. Forest managers use forest management tools to control the fires.   .   in the U.S. forest managers use fire management tools.

articles.title: The Science Behind Global Warming: Separating Fact from Fiction
articles.author: Jan Otte
articles.summary: The topic of global warming is hot. This article aims to shed light on the facts and dispel the myths surrounding the issue. It's time to dive into the science behind this pressing issue and learn more about the facts behind the science of globalwarming. It is not an imminent threat.

articles.title: Fire advisory issued for Lethbridge County
articles.author: David Opinko
articles.summary: Lethbridge County has enacted a fire advisory effective Wednesday, February 26, 2025. Recreational fire pits, incinerators and burn barrels are allowed. If the winds exceed 25 km/h, you must ensure there is a sufficient supply of water on-site to fully extinguish the blaze.

articles.title: 'Droughts, Floods and Fault Lines': Conference on Climate Security in South Asia held
articles.summary: The regional conference titled 'Droughts, Floods, and Fault Lines: Climate Security in South Asia' was held recently at the Renaissance Hotel in Dhaka. The event was organised by The Bangladesh Institute of Peace and Security Studies (BIPSS) and funded by the European Union. It brought together policymakers, experts, and key stakeholders from Nepal, Bhutan, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, India, and Bangladesh to engage in high-level discussions on the intersection of climate change and security in the region.

articles.title: Resilient LBI Team Holds Final Public Information Session
articles.author: Juliet Kaszas-Hoch
articles.summary: The final phase of the Resilient LBI project will be held on March 5th from 6 to 7:30 p.m. on Long Beach Island. The project aims to address the challenges of climate change and sea level rise on the island. The final phase began in October 2023 and runs through March 2025.

articles.title: Delhi Records Season's Hottest Day At 32°C, Air Quality Dips
articles.author: News Mobile Desk
articles.summary: It was the warmest February day in Delhi since February 27, 2023. The minimum temperature was 15.4°C, nearly three degrees higher than usual. The Air Quality Index (AQI) was recorded at 221, placing it in the 'poor' category.

articles.title: 2024 was hottest-ever year on Earth
articles.author: Challis Messenger
articles.summary: Earth recorded its hottest year ever in 2024. Last year's global average temperature easily passed 2023's record heat. It surpassed the long-term warming limit of 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, since the late 1800s, called for by the 2015 Paris climate pact.

articles.title: Uneven heat a climate change peril for poorer postcodes
articles.summary: Older, poorer and regional electorates are those to bear the brunt of extreme heat under unchecked climate change. Lower-income electorates such as Blaxland and Fowler in Sydney's west could expect decent increases in hot days. Maranoa in southwest Queensland would swelter through 172 hot days annually, almost two-fold increase from current averages.

articles.title: Climate Fiction Book Club: The Light Pirate
articles.summary: Iowa City Public Library and Green Iowa Americorps are co-sponsoring a new monthly book club focused on stories about climate change. The book club will meet on 2nd Wednesdays at 6:30 pm at the ICPL. The first book will be The Light Pirate by Lily Brooks-Dalton. Dr. Sarah Outterson-Murphy, teacher and scholar of climate fiction, will facilitate discussion.

articles.title: Uneven heat a climate change peril for poorer postcodes
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Older, poorer and regional electorates are those to bear the brunt of extreme heat under unchecked climate change, according to modelling. The effects of climate change are most likely to be felt in older, poorer, and regional parts of the country, especially in urban areas.

articles.title: Uneven heat a climate change peril for poorer postcodes
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The world is headed towards more moderate warming than the most emissions-intensive pathway modelled by the Climate Council. Such a scenario is possible if countries fail to cut back on fossil fuels, according to Climate Council's chief executive Amanda McKenzie. She says this is possible even if countries don't cut down on emissions.

articles.title: Uneven heat a climate change peril for poorer postcodes
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Older, poorer and regional electorates are those to bear the brunt of extreme heat under unchecked climate change. Lower-income electorates such as Blaxland and Fowler in Sydney's west could expect decent increases in hot days. Maranoa in southwest Queensland would swelter through 172 hot days annually, an almost two-fold increase from current averages.

articles.title: Computer simulations indicate that the probability of a catastrophic disruption in the Atlantic current is reduced in the current century.
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation or AMOC is a key factor in global weather systems. Scientists at the UK's Met Office and the University of Exeter used simulations from 34 different computer models of extreme climate change scenarios to see if the AMOC would collapse this century. No simulation showed a total shutdown before 2100, but it could happen later. The Southern Ocean winds pulling the deep water up act like a powerful pump to keep AMOC running.

articles.title: Krones Climate Transition Plan (Krones AG)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: )Climate Transition Plan is a report about the report on climate change and krones. It explains the basics and framework conditions, the rules by which we act, how we speak and what we mean. It also explains organisation and how it should be done in the future.

articles.title: Total collapse of vital Atlantic currents unlikely this century, study finds
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: The Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (Amoc) is a system of currents that plays a crucial role in the global climate. The Amoc is becoming unstable and approaching a tipping point. Global warming is pushing water temperatures up and increasing the melting of the Greenland ice cap. This means the water is less dense, reducing sinkage and slowing the currents. Amoc has collapsed in the Earth's past.

articles.title: The Science Behind Heatwaves: What's Causing the Rising Temperatures?
articles.author: Jan Otte
articles.summary: In recent years, heatwaves have become more frequent and intense. Understanding the science behind these rising temperatures is more important than ever. Let's dive into the intricate web of factors contributing to this phenomenon and unravel the mystery behind the scorching heat.

articles.title: Worcestershire gritters out as hoar frost predicted
articles.author: Charlotte Albutt
articles.summary: Gritters are going to be seen across Worcestershire tonight (Wednesday) as temperatures are set to fall just below zero degrees and there is a risk of ice and hoar frost. The gritting team will be treating all primary routes from 2am in the morning.

articles.title: Worcestershire gritters out as hoar frost predicted
articles.author: Charlotte Albutt
articles.summary: Gritters are set to be seen across Worcestershire tonight (Wednesday) as temperatures will fall to just below zero degrees. There is a risk of ice and hoar frost overnight. The forecast is for sunny spells intermixed with showers, some heavy this afternoon and clear periods overnight.

articles.title: High school students helping farmers recover from Helene
articles.summary: Helene hit western North Carolina four months ago. The backbone of the state's agriculture industry is still in shambles. Mylee Ponder is a student at North Buncombe High School and the co-president of the school's Future Farmers of America. The organization turned their shop class into a grocery store and their greenhouse into a shopping center. Last week, they distributed more than 1,500 barbed wire and fence posts to local farms in need of fencing repairs.

articles.title: Australian-led research reveals how ancient glaciers help complex life evolve
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Ancient glaciers allowed complex life to flourish by reshaping the Earth's surface. Ancient glaciers scraped deep into Earth's crust and released minerals that changed the chemistry of oceans. Chris Kirkland, lead author of the study from Curtin University in Western Australia, said the findings offered new insights into modern climate change.

articles.title: Green Growth Africa strengthens coastal resilience at Kedzi in V/R
articles.summary: Green Growth Africa's Coastal Resilience and Sustainable Livelihood Initiative (CRESLI) aims to strengthen the resilience of Ghana's coastal communities against climate change. CRESLI has been addressing the devastating effects of rising sea levels, coastal erosion, and dwindling fish stocks in Kedzi, a coastal town in the Keta Municipal Assembly of the Volta Region since its launch in October. A key component of the project has been the restoration of mangroves, which serve as a natural buffer against coastal erosion and support biodiversity. With climate change impacting fishing activities, many women who depend on the trade for their livelihoods are struggling to make ends meet. GGA has been training women

articles.title: Why Greenland's autonomy must be respected
articles.summary: Greenland's future is more important than ever, but it should be decided by its people, not foreign powers, as global competition in the Arctic is heating up.   .      in Greenland's future can be decided only by Greenland's people.

articles.title: Coast Guard urges caution on ice, water as temperatures fluctuate
articles.summary: The Coast Guard urges the public to exercise caution around icy waters as temperatures fluctuate across the Great Lakes region. Temperature fluctuations have impacts on the structural integrity of the ice and could pose safety concerns for those planning to recreate on or near ice and cold water.

articles.title: Green shorelines: Innovative solutions for coastal protection and biodiversity conservation
articles.author: CIMAGGhana
articles.summary: Ghana is a coastal nation with a coastline stretching over 500 kilometers along the Gulf of Guinea. It is increasingly confronted with the impacts of climate change, including coastal erosion, rising sea levels, and the rise of the sea level.

articles.title: 2,500 Scientific Experts Urge Congress & Commerce Secretary to Protect NOAA
articles.author: Union
articles.summary: The Union of Concerned Scientists delivered an open letter to leaders of Congress and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. The letter is signed by more than 2,500 scientists and other experts. It urges them to ensure the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) remains fully funded and staffed and its independent and trusted science is protected.

articles.title: When pollution poisons a community, what does justice look like?
articles.summary: In the American South, systemic disinvestment has left Black, Brown, and Indigenous communities disproportionately vulnerable to environmental hazards and climate disasters. The Partnership for Southern Equity (PSE) is rethinking what's possible, equipping communities to fight for environmental cleanup and advocate for equitable policies.

articles.title: As temperatures soar, IMD issues heatwave warning for coastal Karnataka
articles.author: Express News Service
articles.summary: IMD has issued a heatwave warning for coastal Karnataka districts for the next two days. There is an increased likelihood of illness symptoms in people exposed to the sun for a prolonged period or doing heavy work. The weather is a high health concern for vulnerable people, such as infants, elderly and those with chronic diseases.

articles.title: 4.4M Somalis could face famine by April 2025 due to worsening drought, other factors
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Somali government and UN aid agencies warn that 4.4 million people could go hungry by April 2025 due to worsening drought, conflict, and rising food prices in the Horn of Africa nation. Urgent action is required to save lives, protect livelihoods, and prevent further suffering.

articles.title: Great Lakes ice reached 50% in February. How much ice is there after warm spell?
articles.author: Sarah Moore
articles.summary: The Great Lakes reached their highest percentage of ice coverage in three years on February 22. The last time the Great Lakes ice coverage reached 50% was February 2022 when it hit 56%. Since a warming trend began this week, the total ice coverage decreased to 28.95%. Lake Erie has the most ice coverage at 81.14% due to its shallow depth.

articles.title: Former Malawi leader Joyce Banda honoured for CoP29 contributions
articles.author: Arnold Mnelemba-
articles.summary: Dr. Joyce Banda was appointed as Advisor to the President of Azerbaijan on COP29. She has been recognized for her active participation and contribution in the International Advisory Committee. Dr. Banda is in Cape Town, Republic of South Africa where she is attending the African Leaders Initiative on Debt Relief conference.

articles.title: The reason it's so cold is because of 'global warming' (Video)
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: The reason it's so cold is because of global warming, according to Wide Awake Media's tweet from February 25, 2025, and it's because of "global warming".   .   i   in the tweet.   In the tweet, it's said that the cold is due to global warming.

articles.title: FEMA pauses enforcement of flood protection rules following Trump executive order
articles.author: Peter Castagno
articles.summary: President Donald Trump revoked the flood protection rules on the first day of his second administration. The Federal Flood Risk Management Standard requires projects receiving public assistance money to mitigate flood risk with more stringent design requirements. It applies to a broad range of structures, including public highways, emergency response facilities, schools, and wastewater treatment plants. North Carolina still relies on the International Code Council's 2015 standards for much of the state's building regulations.

articles.title: Maine's spring expected to be warmer than usual
articles.author: Bangor Daily News
articles.summary: This spring in Maine promises another early mud season as the changing climate brings more days above normal temperatures throughout the state. Spring is getting warmer across the U.S. due to heat-trapping. If you think of it as your body temperature rising almost 2 degrees, you wouldn't feel well.

articles.title: 'The climate crisis is killing people.' John Kerry: 'Every year now, millions of people around this planet are dying' as a result of 'greenhouse gas pollution', caused by the way we 'choose to fuel our vehicles… heat our homes, light our factories'.
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: John Kerry warns that the climate crisis is killing people every year and that millions of people are dying as a result of 'greenhouse gas pollution' caused by the way we choose to fuel our vehicles, heat our homes, light our factories and use fossil fuels.

articles.title: Climate Facts: Nigeria one of the worst-hit by extreme weather in 2022, study finds
articles.author: Janefrances Chibundu
articles.summary: Green Climate Fund has approved a $103.2 million grant for seven most climate-vulnerable countries to scale up life-saving early warning systems. Germanywatch says Nigeria was ranked as the 8th most vulnerable country to climate risks globally in 2022. Heatwave was the deadliest extreme weather event with 83 percent ( 61,782) fatalities recorded globally.

articles.title: Low Birth Rates - Governments Are Having A Hissy Fit Over It
articles.summary: The world population now stands at a record high of 8.2 billion people and is growing. Many countries are experiencing fertility rates below the replacement level of about two births per woman. The world population is expected to reach 9 billion by the year 2037, 10 billion by 2060 and 10.2billion by the close of the 21st century.

articles.title: Sewage overflows ‘not good enough', boss of North West water supplier says
articles.author: Anna Wise
articles.summary: 'It is a serious of infrastructure programmes, but at the same time we have to look more long term about how we react to the impacts of climate change, particularly in some of the hot-spots in the North West. 'It's a serious programme, but it's also a serious long-term programme.

articles.title: Climate-related extreme weather events surged 400% over last 50 years: WHO
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: The last 50 years have seen a 400% increase in climate-related extreme weather events due to climate change, according to WHO's World Health Organization (WHO). The last half-century has seen a dramatic surge in such events. The WHO reports that over the past 50 years, the number of such events has increased by 400%.

articles.title: When does daylight saving time start? See 2025 dates, why Texas lawmakers want it to end
articles.author: Alexis Simmerman
articles.summary: Daylight saving time is set to begin on Sunday, March 9, 2025. Time will jump forward by one hour from 2 a.m. to 3 A.M. Central Texas will get around 14 hours of daylight. The longest day of 2025 is Friday, June 20. The shortest day of the year is Sunday, Dec. 21. Texas lawmakers are debating a bill that would keep the state in standard time all year.

articles.title: US climate research agency braces for ‘efficiency' cuts: ‘They will gut the work'
articles.author: Gabrielle Canon
articles.summary: The Trump administration wants to defund the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (Noaa), the US's pre-eminent climate research agency. Noaa provides essential resources to the public and has helped make the US a scientific leader internationally. The agency's scientists, engineers and policy experts issue forecasts relied on by aviation, agriculture and fishing industries, ocean floor mapping and advises on species protection. It is also a primary resource for emergency managers and the public during extreme weather events.

articles.title: Guyanese President announces joint projects with IICA, aimed at strengthening Caribbean agriculture
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: The Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture (IICA) endorsed a strategic plan aimed at bolstering agriculture across Caribbean nations. The initiative was announced by Mohammed Irfaan Ali, the President of Guyana, during the Conference of Heads of Government of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM). This plan places a special emphasis on enhancing local food production. President Ali highlighted the establishment of a Digital Fabrication Laboratory (FabLab) in partnership with IICA.

articles.title: Guyanese President Mohammed Irfaan Ali announces joint projects with IICA, aimed at strengthening Caribbean agriculture
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: The Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture (IICA) endorsed a strategic plan aimed at bolstering agriculture across Caribbean nations. The initiative was announced by Mohammed Irfaan Ali, the President of Guyana, during the Conference of Heads of Government of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM). This plan places a special emphasis on enhancing local food production. President Ali highlighted the establishment of a Digital Fabrication Laboratory (FabLab) in partnership with IICA.

articles.title: California weather has undergone an important shift — and you'll be feeling the impacts soon
articles.author: Jack Lee
articles.summary: All 58 California counties experienced warmer spring temperatures from 1970 to 2024. Temperatures jumped especially in Alaska and the Southwest. A few places, such as in the Dakotas, experienced slightly cooler springs. Scientists attribute the warming trend to human-caused climate change and greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Huon Pine Groves Latest Climate Victims
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Huon Pines on the lower Harman River were burned by the recent wilderness fires. Senator McKim chaired the Senate Inquiry into the response to the 2016 wilderness fires which saw the loss of irreplaceable Pencil Pine forests at Lake Mackenzie. He found that remote area fires need to be hit hard and early with aerial resources, before they can become established.

articles.title: Mild temperatures today, 2-4 cm of snow in Ottawa on Election Day
articles.author: Josh Pringle
articles.summary: The snow is slowly melting on Ottawa streets following mild temperatures this week, which is making it easier to remove it from the roads.      Â   - Andrew Adlington/CTV News Ottawa.  -Andrew Adlington  - Ottawa News Ottawa

articles.title: 19. Religion and views on the environment
articles.author: Gregory A. Smith
articles.summary: Most U.S. adults believe that God gave humans a duty to protect and care for the Earth and a right to use the Earth for humanity's benefit, according to the 2023-24 Religious Landscape Study (RLS). Highly religious Americans are the most likely to say that. Few Americans with low levels of religious engagement believe God gave people the right to protect the Earth or to use it for humanity’s benefit. People who are not religious tend to identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party.

articles.title: ‘Worst was behind us': Inflation ticks up in January under Labor
articles.summary: Australia's inflation has ticked up again in January under the Labor government. Sky News host Paul Murray believes the worst is behind us and that Australia is on its way to a greater and more amazing future under the new government's policies. He believes the inflation is nothing to see here.

articles.title: Letters to the editor for Wednesday, February 26, 2025
articles.author: Letter writers
articles.summary: Cape Coral families are concerned about the proposed Redfish Pointe development among wetlands south of Rotary Park. They want to march on Saturday, March 1, at 9 a.m. to protest the development. The march is held just days before the Planning and Zoning Commission is scheduled to address the issue.

articles.title: Chinese warship drills are ‘not important' to the Prime Minister
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese's government is not focused on the issue of Chinese warships engaging in live-fire drills off the coast of Australia, says Strategic Analysis Australia Director Peter Jennings. Mr Jennings claims the prime minister is not demanding the pace of information he needs to get from the defence.

articles.title: Doctors issue urgent warning as malaria cases are on the rise: 'It will make the world a less safe place'
articles.author: Mandy Carr
articles.summary: There is an increase in malaria cases in Uganda due to more extreme weather events. The Ministry of Health has a five-year strategy for combating climate-related diseases. It includes leadership development, community engagement, and "the construction of climate-resilient health infrastructure."

articles.title: Arry Simon from the Department of Environment is representing Antigua and Barbuda in Hangzhou, China
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: IPCC Delegates are meeting in Hangzhou, China, from February 24-28, 2025, to review key elements of the Seventh Assessment Report (AR7). Small Island Developing States are actively participating in the IPCC process. They are pushing for stronger focus on limiting global warming to 1.5°C and enhanced adaptation strategies.

articles.title: Beaches north of Barcelona have lost 30,100m2 of sand in five years
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: The Metropolitan Area of Barcelona (AMB) has warned that the beaches north of Barcelona have lost about 30,100 square meters of sand in the last five years. Montgat has lost 70% of its beach surface in four years due to storms. The only coastline that has gained sand is Sant Adrià de Besòs.

articles.title: The Greening of the Antarctic Peninsula
articles.author: Brandon Withrow
articles.summary: Antarctica experienced an unprecedented heat wave last year, with temperatures 50 degrees above normal. Phytoplankton are responsible for every second breath of oxygen we take. The study in Nature shows that climate change and its increasing temperatures are helping that green-up to expand.

articles.title: Beaches north of Barcelona have lost 30,100m2 of sand in five years
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: The beaches north of Barcelona have lost 30,100 square meters of sand in the last five years, according to AMB's study on climate change trends in the metropolitan area.       in the study on the 'Study on Climate Change Trends in the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona'

articles.title: Editorial: The tale of New Isle should be a warning for Louisiana
articles.author: STAFF EDITORIAL
articles.summary: Isle de Jean Charles in Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana, is disappearing due to rising sea levels. The state government built a new community, New Isle, further inland and on higher ground. It offered to resettle residents there for free, giving them houses as a pilot program that made islanders the nation's first "climate refugees". The cost of relocating 37 households has been almost $50 million.

articles.title: Residents in northwest Toronto neighbourhood brace for flooding as warmer weather melts snow
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Residents in one Toronto neighbourhood are worried about water in their basements as snow on the streets begins to melt due to a rise in temperature and they are concerned about flooding in the basements due to the rise in temperatures.   in the northwest Toronto neighbourhood.

articles.title: Vanuatu climate minister frets over US climate reversal
articles.summary: Vanuatu's climate change minister Ralph Regenvanu is worried about the potential impact of President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. Pacific archipelago has struggled with natural disasters and with creeping seas eating away at its fertile coastal fringe. Vanuatu had the largest military base in the South Pacific during World War II.

articles.title: Climate COMPASS: Islanders invited to shape San Juan County's climate future
articles.summary: Join fellow islanders on March 8 from 3-5 p.m. at Emmanuel Episcopal Parish Hall for the Comprehensive Plan Outreach for Meaningful Public Action & Sustainable Solutions, or COMPASS. San Juan County is updating its Comprehensive Plan and adding climate resiliency to the agenda. The project is a collaborative effort led by Faith Van De Putte and Chom Greacen, in partnership with the Madrona Institute, Friends of the San Juans and the family resource centers on San Juan, Orcas and Lopez.

articles.title: Somerset starling display before a murmuration captured on film
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: A swarm of starlings have been filmed swirling just above the ground in a murmuration-like display. The phenomena was recorded near Ashcott on the Somerset Levels last week and was filmed by a passerby.   Â     .

articles.title: Somerset starling display before a murmuration captured on film
articles.summary: A swarm of starlings has been filmed swirling just above the ground in a murmuration-like display. The phenomena was recorded near Ashcott on the Somerset Levels last week and has been viewed by tens of thousands of people on social media. The starling murmuration is the largest in North Western Europe.

articles.title: No major floods expected in Latvia this spring
articles.summary: In the coming days, rivers are expected to see a slight rise in water levels. Water levels will depend mainly on precipitation. If there is little rain, the ice will not start to move and will melt on the spot. Daugava and Plaviņas reservoirs may experience sharp fluctuations during the ice advance due to the existing ice compaction. There is some compaction of ice in the Gauja, Lielupe and Ogre rivers.

articles.title: Ideas & Opinions — Sandra Safran: One teeny, tiny action
articles.author: Sandra Safran
articles.summary: If you don't believe in climate change, then you are either deaf, blind, uninformed, lazy, or submissive. The signs are obvious: the temperature is rising and the climate is changing in a negative way. It's not a natural phenomenon.

articles.title: Coast Guard warns people to stay off ice
articles.author: CNHI News Service
articles.summary: The U.S. Coast Guard is warning people to be extremely cautious as the Great Lakes water temperatures will remain dangerously cold posing safety concerns for anyone venturing on the lakes. Warmer air temperatures will cause frozen waters to melt at an alarming rate and may cause misperceptions about Great Lakes temperature.

articles.title: Scientists Aid Darwinites in Heat Battle Tonight
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Darwin Living Lab portal is a new interactive tool developed by CSIRO to help manage the impact of rising temperatures in Australia's tropical capital. CSIRO also runs an Urban Living Lab project at Sydney Science Park in Western Sydney and has plans for another at Ginninderra in Canberra.

articles.title: Forest fires drive up Ukraine war emissions
articles.author: Ros Davidson
articles.summary: The war in Ukraine has generated nearly 230mn tonnes of CO2-equivalent (CO2e) emissions since Russia's full-scale invasion began. In the past year alone, CO2e emissions linked to the war reached 55mn tonnes. The largest contributor to emissions remains direct warfare, accounting for 36% of the total since 2022. Reconstruction, particularly rebuilding homes, hospitals, roads and other infrastructure accounted for 62.2mn tonnes (27%). Civil aviation, which has seen increased emissions due to planes rerouting around Russian airspace, and refugee movements contributed 2%.

articles.title: 'Provocative' Chinese warship near Australia puts Japan on notice
articles.author: STAFF WRITER
articles.summary: China's recent deployment of three warships to waters east of Australia was "designed to be provocative' according to Andrew Shearer, Australia's director-general of national intelligence. Last week, the Chinese naval flotilla conducted an unusual series of live-fire exercises in the seas between Australia and New Zealand.

articles.title: Nuclear Thuggery: House Report on Energy Threats
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Friends of the Earth welcomes the Interim Report released by the House Select Committee on Nuclear Energy. Kooyong MP Dr. Monique Ryan concludes that an "ongoing pursuit of nuclear energy options will only perpetuate and increase Australia's reliance on coal and gas". FoE Australia's national nuclear campaigner Dr. Jim Green says nuclear power is too expensive and too slow.

articles.title: Snowball Earth: A Deep Freeze Journey Through Earth's Cryogenian Period
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Cryogenian period, roughly 700 million years ago, saw immense glaciers encase the planet in ice, stretching from pole to equator. New findings show the critical role of these glaciations in Earth's geological and biological evolution. Theories suggest a decline in atmospheric carbon dioxide triggered the Cryogenician deep freezes, influenced by tropical weathering and tectonic shifts. Volcanoes ended these ice ages by enhancing atmospheric CO2, sparking global warming.

articles.title: Vanuatu climate minister frets over US climate reversal
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Vanuatu's climate minister is worried about the potential impact of President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. Vanuatu is a low-lying island nation in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. It's worried about possible consequences of the anti-climate change bent of the new US government.

articles.title: Collaboration Aids WA Scientists in Marine Heatwave Study
articles.author: James Gilmour
articles.summary: A major coral bleaching is affecting Western Australian reefs. It is of particular concern because of its timing and scale. Western Australia's coral reefs are as extensive geographically and as diverse as those found in the Great Barrier Reef. They are well managed systems with a range of protections in place via state and federal marine parks. Western Australian Coral Bleaching Group was formed 10 years ago to discuss and monitor the bleaching of WA reefs.

articles.title: Floods and Lightning in Helmand leave 5 dead, 6 injured
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: There was heavy rainfall and flooding in the districts of Sangin, Musa Qala, and Babaji in Helmand province. Five people died and six were injured as a result of the floods. In Farah province, 21 people, including women and children, lost their lives due to flooding.

articles.title: MET predicts wet end to February
articles.author: NT Bureau
articles.summary: After a month of dry weather, Tamil Nadu is set to receive rain starting from February 26th. Scattered rainfall is expected over the south coastal and delta regions on February 28 and March 1st. The rains are triggered by a cyclonic circulation moving over the equatorial region and interacting with an easterly trough.

articles.title: Environmental Indicators Dashboard
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The EIA Environmental Indicators Dashboard displays charts, statistics, and maps based on the best scientific information about ecosystems in Australia. It shows data including ecosystem distribution, protection levels, changes in species, including endangered ones, over time. It is part of Australia's efforts to follow the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, which has 23 targets to reach by 2030.

articles.title: Creating a sustainable landscape: a guide to permeable solutions
articles.author: Sasha Harrison
articles.summary: Sustainable landscaping should be an essential part of a community's future. Impermeable surfaces can overwhelm stormwater systems due to flooding. They absorb heat and carry pollutants into nearby water sources. They can also negatively affect the health of humans and wildlife alike.

articles.title: Plants losing appetite for carbon dioxide amid effects of warming climate
articles.author: Kate Ravilious
articles.summary: Earth's plants and soils reached peak carbon dioxide sequestration in 2008. Since then the amount of carbon dioxide absorbed by plants has declined by an average of 0.25% a year. Emissions need to fall by 0.3% per year just to stand still.

articles.title: Brisbane City Council begins early planned burns to tackle fire risk
articles.author: Sofie Formica
articles.summary: The Brisbane City Council is starting early with planned burns this year. Crews will burn 45 hectares at Kholo Bushland Reserve starting today. Bernard Trembath from Queensland Bushfire Planning joined Sofie Formica on 4BC Afternoons to discuss planned burns.

articles.title: 29 fatalities caused by hail and rain in Afghanistan
articles.summary: 29 people died in two provinces in Afghanistan due to hail and heavy rainfall. In Farah, 21 people were killed and six others were injured because of hail. In Kandahar, 8 people died because of heavy rainfall and a roof fell on a family. Afghanistan is one of the world's most vulnerable countries to climate change.

articles.title: New Model Predicts U.S. Disaster Displacement Length
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: 1.1% of American households were displaced due to disasters between December 2022 and July 2024. Displaced households in Louisiana and Florida were about 6.8 and 4.4 times more likely to be displaced than in the national average, but they returned home faster than those in many other states.

articles.title: Sonam Wangchuk Urges Action on Glacier Conservation to Protect Sacred Rivers from Climate Change
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: The glaciers of the Himalayas are rapidly melting. In a few decades, rivers such as the Ganga, Brahmaputra, and Indus may only flow seasonally. The next Mahakumbh could be celebrated on the dry remnants of these sacred rivers. India must take a proactive role in addressing the adverse effects of climate change.

articles.title: How adaptation gap is worsening Africa's climate crisis
articles.author: Wambui Mbuthia
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, Africa's capacity to adapt to climate change impacts lags behind the scale of the challenge. More than 60 per cent of Africa's livelihoods depend on climate-sensitive sectors like agriculture. Africa's debt burden limits fiscal space for adaptation measures. Global adaptation finance needs are 10-18 times higher than current public flows.

articles.title: Homelessness is a shared struggle
articles.author: Times Leader
articles.summary: Melissa Sanger is a staff writer for PETA. She is concerned about the human-induced climate catastrophe that is fueling a housing crisis. The same wildfires, hurricanes and floods that leave human families homeless also force wildlife from their homes. People who eat a lot of meat are responsible for nearly two and a half times as many dietary greenhouse gas emissions per day as vegans.

articles.title: Mersin farmers light stoves overnight as cold threatens crops
articles.summary: The unrelenting cold front continues to grip the southern city of Mersin, pushing agricultural workers to light stoves through the night in a diligent bid to shield from frost and protect crops. In Eastern Anatolia, the Siberian cold wave made life even harsher and more challenging for citizens.

articles.title: Funding sought for critically damaged Pass-a-Grille seawall
articles.author: Josh Rojas
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene's storm surge damaged critical infrastructure in Pass-a-Grille including a beach wall, road and seawall. The estimated cost to repair the seawall is $5 million. The Gulf Way Roadway and beach wall is estimated to cost $2.2 million. FEMA will inspect both projects on March 11.

articles.title: ‘Sustainable' investors flee references to climate change
articles.author: Saijel Kishan
articles.summary: Garvin Jabusch used to show a chart of the planet's rising temperatures when pitching investment ideas to clients. Now he avoids talking about climate change. He manages about $300 million in Denver, Colorado. He has given up on anyone caring about that.

articles.title: Alarm ringing
articles.author: Gwynne Dyer
articles.summary: The average global temperature has risen by 1.75°C since June 2023. This is because of the greenhouse gases emitted by humans. The Earth System monitors the Earth System for the European Union. A wiser civilisation would be discussing emergency measures right now, even if it takes longer.

articles.title: University of Vienna Launches Global Demography Program
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Wittgenstein Centre for Demography and Global Human Capital (IIASA, OeAW, University of Vienna) will start Master's Programme "Global Demography" at Vienna with its fifth cohort of students in October 2025. The principal aim of the master's programme is to give students a strong scientific grounding in the analysis and forecasting of demographic developments.

articles.title: Climate risk insurance: the missing links
articles.author: Dr Muhammad Faisal Ali
articles.summary: Pakistan is one of the most vulnerable countries to climate change. Climate Risk Index 2025 ranked Pakistan as the most affected country globally for the year 2022. Floods in 2010 and more recently in 2022 were among the most disastrous. Climate risk insurance provides immediate relief and a safety net to vulnerable individuals and institutions.

articles.title: Rise in temperatures signifies regular seasonal transition, meteorologists say
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: A recent spike in temperatures across large parts of China is a normal transitional phase between winter and spring, according to weather experts. The transition from winter to spring is marked by volatile temperature changes, with cold fronts quickly followed by warm spells, as experts say.

articles.title: A 3000-year-old pine intact but ancient trees scorched
articles.author: Abe Maddison
articles.summary: Jeremy Rockliff and Anthony Albanese are responsible for stoking greater global heating, through more coal mines, gas fracking and forest burning. Mr Brown challenges them to visit burnt pines with him and see the destruction for themselves. He is concerned future Tasmanian fires will be even more disastrous.

articles.title: Climate Change in Pakistan
articles.summary: Pakistan has experienced increasingly severe weather due to climate change. The coastal city of Gwadar in Balochistan has been badly affected by flooding and rising sea levels. The situation is worsening every year. The government of Pakistan needs to take urgent action to address the problem.

articles.title: What happened to NZ birds the last time the climate changed
articles.summary: When humans arrived in New Zealand they set about dramatic changes to the landscape, which in turn impacted birdlife. A new study from the University of Otago is looking back further to the ice age to see how birdlife responded during that period.

articles.title: Bengaluru basks in 33 Degree C, but heat is on in Karnataka
articles.author: Sridhar Vivan
articles.summary: IMD has issued a heatwave warning for the next three days in three districts in Karnataka. High relative humidity and high air temperatures increase the risk of heat-related illnesses. People are advised to avoid direct sunlight between 12 pm and 3 pm, drink ample water, wear light-coloured clothing and cover the head with a hat, cloth, or umbrella.

articles.title: Lethbridge Fire and EMS training for ice rescues ahead of spring melt
articles.summary: Lethbridge Fire and Emergency Services is preparing to help people who fall through the ice on lakes and ponds due to warmer weather.    Lethbridges Fire and emergency services is preparing for the possibility of people falling through the icy surface.

articles.title: Climate-related extreme weather events surged 400% over last 50 years: WHO
articles.author: İlayda Çakırtekin
articles.summary: There has been a 400% increase in extreme weather events due to climate change in the last 50 years, according to the WHO Regional Office for Europe. The UN agency also pointed to the impact of climate change on various health issues, including infectious diseases, respiratory and non-communicable diseases, mental health, and injuries such as drownings.

articles.title: Climate change poses economic risks
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Climate change is a major threat to Fiji's economy. Rising sea levels and more frequent natural disasters are also putting pressure on the country's economy, especially due to sea levels rise and natural disasters such as floods and droughts, which are caused by climate change.

articles.title: 2024 hottest year on record for Cameron Highlands, says environment minister
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Temperatures in Cameron Highlands rose by 0.86% over the past 10 years, according to the Dewan Rakyat. It is higher than the average for Kuala Lumpur and for the whole of Malaysia.   Â£1,868 per square kilometer.

articles.title: Veteran Meteorologist James Spann Voices Support for NOAA and NWS in Anticipation of Trump Cuts
articles.author: Adweek
articles.summary: WBMA chief meteorologist James Spann supports the National Weather Service and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Spann is a strong supporter of the NWS and NOAA.    for the WBMA. For more information, go to: www.wba.org.

articles.title: Housing experts want more apartments in Australia's regional cities
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Experts say there's a cultural shift underway in Australia and more people are wanting to live in smaller, more central homes. They say the housing industry and regulators aren't keeping up with the trend.      Â   in Australia.

articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Earth's plants and soils reached peak carbon dioxide sequestration in 2008. The proportion absorbed has been declining since, study finds. The percentage absorbed has also been declining, according to the study.   .   i   in the study:

articles.title: Hitting climate emission reduction targets - what it will mean for UK households
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: Climate advisors are urging the UK to slash its greenhouse gas emissions by 87% by 2040. To do so will change everyday activities like heating homes, driving and flying and even what we keep in our fridges.   .   in this article we stated that

articles.title: Middle powers such as Australia relied on the rules-based order, but that's in doubt. Here's ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: US globalism is in retreat and Australia's fear of abandonment is more acute than in ages. Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast to stay up to date with the latest news from Australia and the world. iReport: Australia and globalism are in retreat.

articles.title: Energy reserves are dictating US policy
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Greenland is not green, it has a polar climate and over 85 per cent of its land area is permanent ice-sheet. Geopolitically, it is part of Europe, falling under the Kingdom of Denmark, but geographically, it's part of the North American continent. Donald Trump thinks Greenland will get because it has to do with freedom.

articles.title: Volatile Climate Splits Weather Agencies on El Ni�o�Messaging
articles.author: Live Mint
articles.summary: An accurate read is essential for governments, energy markets and farmers. Global warming exacerbates extreme weather, so an accurate reading is essential.    for governments and energy markets, especially as global warming exacerbating extreme weather. For farmers, accurate readings are essential for survival.

articles.title: Floods in the midwest, hurricanes in Appalachia: there were never any climate havens
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Recent disasters show the need for a different way of thinking about climate-proof communities in the United States, as one analyst says.   "The other part of it, knocking the rest of it down" is the solution to climate-related disasters.

articles.title: Why where you live could ‘speed up the ageing process' – as study warns areas ...
articles.author: The Sun
articles.summary: Living in places hit by heatwaves can make your body age faster. American scientists tracked how thousands of people's biological ages changed over time, and found that the weather can slow down or speed up the aging process depending on the place you live, according to the study.

articles.title: England's fly-tipping crisis: Ministers pledge clampdown as illegal dumping hits six-year high - find out ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Fly-tipping in England has risen to its highest level in almost 20 years, official figures reveal today. Environment Secretary Steve Reed vowed to toughen up enforcement after reported cases of illegal dumping passed 1.15million in 2023/24. The figure is an increase of 6 per cent from the 1.08 million in 2010.

articles.title: Climate change: AMOC likely to withstand future warming (MET Office - Meteorological Office)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is unlikely to collapse this century. AMOC is a major transporter of heat to the north Atlantic and northwestern Europe. It is likely to withstand future warming, according to Grahame Madge.

articles.title: Meltdown at the top of the world
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: 2025 is the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation. The world's ice sheets are melting due to climate change. The Hindu Kush Himalaya region is the Earth's 'Third Pole' because of the melting of the ice sheets in the Himalayas, especially in the Hindu Kush.

articles.title: Getting Ready: How we can all live lightly and help heal the planet
articles.author: Foster's Daily Democrat
articles.summary: The new Trump administration has signaled an exit from the Paris Climate Agreement, but people can still affect their own participation in the agreement by voting on issues affecting their own well-being, such as the production of fossil fuels and undoing Biden-era initiatives to limit greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Ancient glacier finding reveals clues to how complex life on Earth evolved, scientists say
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: More than half a billion years ago on a frigid, ice-covered Earth, there was a planet with a rocky surface. It was covered by a thick layer of ice. There was no water on the planet at the time. It had a thick atmosphere.

articles.title: Total collapse of vital Atlantic currents unlikely this century, study finds
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Even weakened currents would cause profound harm to humanity, according to climate scientists.    -     .   and the current is not a threat to humanity but to the environment. "Even weakened" currents would be harmful to humanity.

articles.title: ‘Human activity on a massive scale': a photo exhibition tackles the climate crisis
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Photographs from across the globe capture the impact of people on the climate and of the climate on people, as well as on the environment.   .   i.e. the people's impact on climate and the environment, and on people.

articles.title: Delusional clowns of ‘Climate Change Committee' are turning UK into laughing stock
articles.author: The Sun
articles.summary: The 'Climate Change Committee' advises the Government that they are leading the world towards Net Zero. Heeding them would make us into a laughing stock. Ed Miliband would prefer to ignore them, as he would like to do. He would like us to live in a world without net zero.

articles.title: Cartoonist's take: ‘Climate change'
articles.author: Daily Freeman
articles.summary: 'Climate change' is the subject of a cartoon in the Salt Lake Tribune, Utah, via CagleCartoons.com. The cartoon is by Pat Bagley, a cartoonist from Utah, and is based on the newspaper's opinion piece.

articles.title: Flight costs must rise to curb aviation emissions, climate advisers warn
articles.author: London Evening Standard
articles.summary: The Climate Change Committee is being less prescriptive on airport capacity than in previous advice to the Government. It is being 'less prescriptIVE' than in earlier advice to Government.   Â      in the Climate Change committee.

articles.title: This ‘great' barrier reef is an elite snorkelers' secret with whale sharks and a luxury ...
articles.author: New York Post
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef is one of Australia's biggest draws. It attracted 2.4 million tourists to its vast marine park last year. It is more than 2,100 miles away from Australia's island continent, which is about the same distance from the island continent.

articles.title: Australian-led research reveals how ancient glaciers help complex life evolve
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Ancient glaciers allowed complex life to flourish by reshaping the Earth's surface. When the ice sheets melted, they triggered floods that flushed minerals and their chemicals into the oceans, including uranium, into the ocean. The research was done by researchers from Australia, the UK and Canada.

articles.title: US climate research agency braces for ‘efficiency' cuts: ‘They will gut the work'
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Workers at National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration fear crackdown will have global fallout for the agency and its workers. They fear it will have a negative impact on the global economy.    for the U.S. and for the rest of the world.

articles.title: Compensation on cards for frozen solar water heating panels
articles.author: Cyprus Mail
articles.summary: Icy weather damaged uninsulated pipes and rooftop solar water heating panels on the island. Local authorities are collecting information on the number of homeowners affected. A decision to compensate them is to be made soon.   . .

articles.title: Scientists discover extreme heat can accelerate aging
articles.author: Talker
articles.summary: People living in areas with more hot weather days show faster aging at the molecular level than residents of cooler regions, according to a study by the University of Southern California USC Leonard Davis School of Gerontology. The study looked at 3,600 participants aged 56 and older from across the U.S. and compared their changes in biological age to their location's heat index history.

articles.title: Searing heat, delayed rain season explained
articles.author: Gerald Tenywa
articles.summary: Temperatures are usually high in the dry season, but experts say there has been a big increase this February due to the increase in the number of days with above-average temperatures this year.      Â   for February.

articles.title: EarthTalk: What Dismantling USAID Means For Climate & Environment
articles.author: Florida Fish
articles.summary: President Trump wants to dismantle the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). USAID has been a leader in global environmental efforts, supporting initiatives that promote sustainability, cut emissions and build resilience in vulnerable regions. USAID's Climate Strategy (2022-2030) outlines a plan for reducing emissions, enhancing resilience and promoting sustainable development across multiple sectors and regions.
